Award.AwardTitle: Integrative Middle School STEM Teacher Preparation: A Collaborative Capacity Building Project at Duke University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a long-standing shortage of qualified and highly-qualified middle grades math and science teachers in high-need school districts. This shortage forces many schools, a disproportionately large number in high-minority and high-poverty communities, to lower hiring standards to fill teaching vacancies, in turn leading to high levels of underqualified mathematics and science teachers and lower student achievement in STEM subjects. Through this Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Capacity Building grant, Duke University's Program in Education will expand its long-standing partnership with Durham Public Schools and Duke STEM departments to design and institutionalize an innovative, middle grades (6-8) Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) STEM teacher preparation program to recruit, prepare, and retain diverse STEM graduates and professionals to be highly qualified middle school math and science teachers of culturally, linguistically, and cognitively diverse students in high-need school districts.

This project will use research findings from a previous Noyce Scholarship project and data gathered during a national needs assessment to establish the infrastructure for a Phase I Noyce Scholarship grant by designing and institutionalizing an integrative MAT teacher licensure program that includes a teaching internship in a high-need middle school. Investigators will use a backwards-design approach to create a rigorous set of program outcomes aligned with state standards for STEM teacher preparation. Despite the enduring shortage of qualified or highly-qualified middle school math and science teachers, there is surprisingly limited empirical research on middle school math and science teacher recruitment among highly-successful STEM graduates. This project will lay the groundwork for a Phase I grant proposal that will further research in the recruitment, preparation, and support of diverse groups of STEM graduates and professionals to become highly-effective middle school math and science teachers in high-need school districts. Key documents, such as the Conceptual Framework, Course of Study, Clinical Experiences Plan, Syllabi, and Degree Requirements, will be reviewed by an external evaluator to determine how and to what degree program objectives are being met. A High-Needs Rubric will be created to determine the extent to which the Duke Middle Grades MAT program design meets the needs of STEM education in high-need middle schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Duke University Program in Education, in collaboration with the Durham Public Schools and the STEM departments in Trinity College of Arts and Sciences, investigated the institutionalization of an innovative middle grades (6-8) Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) STEM teacher preparation program designed to recruit, prepare, and retain diverse STEM graduates and professionals to be highly qualified middle school math and science teachers in high-need school districts.

A national needs assessment was conducted among STEM major undergraduate students to determine STEM students’ perceptions of middle grades science and math teaching. Findings (n= 138) helped identify needs and inform program design of a middle grades teacher preparation program. In addition, the needs assessment helped the Program in Education identify a substantial recruitment pool (respondents were undergraduates from 16 universities across the U.S.). In addition, public school partners identified the need for: 1) A pool of licensed and highly qualified middle grades Mathematics and Science teachers (current shortage of licensed STEM teachers? majority of applicants are lateral entry); 2)  STEM content mastery for middle grades teachers; and 3) Content specific methods courses (in teacher preparation programs) that support the ‘middle school concept’ (teaming, project-based learning, integration of writing in STEM areas, differentiation).

Aside from determining the needs of stakeholders, one of the initial key tasks of the project was to review and summarize research on middle grades STEM programs across the country with the goal of identifying models outside "traditional approaches" to preparing middle grades STEM teachers within a MAT framework. Based on a thorough review and ongoing team discussions, only a few MAT middle grades teacher preparation programs with innovative aspects to their preparation of middle school teachers were located. However, various non-traditional community-based approaches to teacher preparation emerged such as Teacher Residency Models as did innovative pedagogies such as project-based teaching and learning, place-based pedagogy, and maker-centered learning for STEM classrooms.

In Year 2 of the project, 13 successful middle schools across the country were visited. These visits included classroom observations and interviews with classroom teachers and school administrators. The objective of these school visits was to determine the characteristics of successful middle schools and their teachers. Several themes emerged from an analysis of the site visit reports. These themes highlight the importance of the following qualities in excellent middle school teachers: a strong understanding of students and the communities in which they live? the ability to develop responsive educational spaces that support the individual learners while maintaining high expectations? the capacity to teach beyond the standards-based curriculum to encourage creativity and curiosity? and the ability to use technology to support active, hands-on instruction.

Information gleaned from Years 1-2 of the project served as the basis for creating a proposed structure for how a middle grades STEM teacher preparation might be launched at Duke University. After considerable discussion among faculty within education and the mathematics and science departments, it was determined that integrating a middle grades MAT program within an existing secondary (grades 9-12) MAT program was within our current capacity.  In addition, creating a dual track licensure program (middle school + high school) has many advantages for both programs.

The curriculum of the current secondary MAT program was examined and content was modified to address middle grades pedagogy and early adolescent development. In addition, current secondary MAT scholars student teach for 27 weeks at two different high schools.  For those students desiring to pursue the dual track, one of these placements will be in a middle school. In terms of content knowledge, MAT students are already required to take 5 courses in their content area (Math or Science). 

By providing a dual track licensure option (middle + high school), Duke's teacher preparation program will have a competitive edge among other middle grades teacher preparation programs. The new program will also hopefully increase future enrollment in Duke's MAT programs in science and mathematics. Teachers completing the program will also be highly desired by school systems due to their range of content and pedagogical knowledge and flexibility for moving across grade levels within the system. 

Due to changes in the new program approval process by the North Carolina Department of Public Instruction, a proposal to support middle grades scholars will not be submitted until the 2018 Noyce competition.  The proposal will include a research component to monitor the impact of vertical content knowledge on teacher self-efficacy and 6-12 student achievement as well as the relationship between broader pedadogical knowledge and student achievement across various developmental and readiness levels.
